items.message:
Storm Ciaran has cleared, and river levels are continuing to fall throughout today.
Catchments are saturated and a persistent band of rainfall is expected Saturday morning. We expect river levels to respond to this rainfall, though no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not expected to be issued.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Church Wilne river gauge as a result of Storm Ciaron.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Church Wilne, Draycott, and Wilne Lane between Draycott and Sawley.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 04/11/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are falling at the Ashford river gauge as a result of Storm Ciaron.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Ashford and Bakewell areas.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to begin rising again tonight 03/11/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels remain very high after heavy rainfall from Storm Ciarán. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the New Romney Sewage Arm, particularly at Greatstone.   
Further heavy rainfall is forecast from around 5am on Saturday 04/11/23 and is expected to continue until the evening. As a result, river levels may rise again during Saturday. Our incident response staff have deployed pumps, people and equipment to Greatstone Pumping Station and we are actively monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths or gardens near the watercourse and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated on Saturday morning, 04/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Erewash in Derbyshire and Nottinghamshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.56m and is stable.

Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.

The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 6.20 m and is rising by approximately 30 mm per hour.

There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30 m.

Pumping is taking place at Saltmoor and Northmoor pumping stations.

Scattered showers are forecast for today 03/11/2023 and a heavier band of rain Saturday morning.

The River Tone at Currymoor is forecast to remain high as a result.

Flooding is possible in this area.

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

Over the last few days we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Witham area. This means that the River Witham remains high, and we will continue to see flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online if the situation changes.

items.description: The River Bure, Spixworth Beck and surrounding Becks
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Friday 3 November 2023. River levels are currently high, but are expected to start to drop back down to more normal levels later today. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas between Horsford and Crostwick on the Spixworth Beck, and Corpusty, Saxthorpe, Itteringham, Ingworth, Aylsham and Burgh-next-Aylsham on the Bure. The forecast is for largely dry conditions with occasional showers today. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message on Saturday 4 November 2023 or as the situation changes.

Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the Barlings Eau and Duckpool catchwater area. This means that water levels remain high and we will continue to see flooding of low-lying land and roads close to watercourses. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties is likely and therefore the Lower Barlings and Short Ferry area warning remains in place. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline if the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are still rising at the Shardlow and Willington river gauge as a result of Storm Ciaron.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Ingleby, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows at Willington,  Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday 05/11/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 04/11/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Frisby river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Mill Lane and Water Lane at Frisby on the Wreake, Station Road at Thrussington, Broome Lane at Ratcliffe on the Wreake, Frisby, farmlands at Hoby, Brooksby, Thrussington, Ratcliffe and Syston.   
 We expect river levels to remain high until later tonight on 3/11/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 04/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Following heavy rainfall in the Low Barlings and Short Ferry catchment water levels in the Barlings Eau remain high. Low lying areas near to watercourses are flooded and we expect properties to be affected. We urge residents in Short Ferry Caravan Park to remain vigilant and stay up to date with the latest advice. Further rainfall is forecast for Saturday 4th November and therefore river levels will remain high. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Please avoid contact with flood water.  Our staff are out in the area to check the flood defences, clear blockages, and assist the emergency services and council.  We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated online and on FloodLine as the situation changes.

items.description: River Witham and associated Fens from Washingborough to Metheringham
items.message: Following Storm Babet and subsequent heavy rainfall, water levels in the Witham Catchment remain high. We are actively monitoring the bank of the river near Fiskerton village, and have installed cameras to monitor the location continuously. We have agreed an action plan with the Local Resilience Forum should circumstances change. We urge residents in Fiskerton village, Short Ferry Caravan Park and properties along Ferry Road area to remain vigilant, and stay up to date with the latest advice. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

Flooding is possible in this area.

items.description: The River Waveney from Diss to Bungay
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is likely today, Friday 3 November 2023. River levels are expected to continue to rise. Areas most at risk are riverside areas in Homersfield, Needham Mill, Brockdish, Scole and Diss, including the A143 at Scole and Homersfield, and the A1066 at Diss. The forecast is for largely dry conditions with occasional showers today. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message on Saturday 4 November 2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - St George's Field and Queen's Staith
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse due to heavy rain associated with Storm Ciaran.  River levels have peaked at the York Viking recorder. River levels are expected to remain high into the weekend. Flooding is expected at properties along Queen's Staith, on South Esplanade, Friars Terrace and Tower Place. Flooding is also expected at St George's Field carpark and Rowntree Park. Our incident rooms are open and we are closely monitoring the situation. The Foss Barrier is operating and floodgates along the river in York have been closed. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:30 on Saturday, 04/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse in York due to rainfall associated with Storms Babet and Ciaran. Levels are now peaking at 3.5m at York Viking Recorder. Areas most at risk include riverside properties through central York. Flood gates are closed throughout the city. Our incident room is open and we are carrying out operational activities, including operating the Foss Barrier. Flood gates near the river remain closed. Consider putting your flood plan into action. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 07:00 on Saturday, 04/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels are rising steadily in response to recent rainfall.  Flooding is expected on the Hundred Foot (Ouse) Washes for several days.   This information is correct as of 15:45 on 3/11/23. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 8 centimetres of water on the road. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. There are currently no issues on the Earith causeway. The causeway at Welney is likely to become inundated overnight or tomorrow morning, some ponding on the road has already been observed.  The Environment Agency is liaising with Cambridgeshire & Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the causeways. Further rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours which will keep river levels high, while floodwater is also travelling down the River Great Ouse towards the Ouse Washes.   Avoid driving through flood water. We are monitoring the situation, we will update this message by 8am tomorrow, 4/11/23.

This message will be updated by 09:30 AM on Saturday, 04/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Storm Ciaran has cleared, and river levels are continuing to fall throughout today.
Catchments are saturated and a persistent band of rainfall is expected Saturday morning. We expect river levels to respond to this rainfall, though no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not expected to be issued.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

Further heavy rainfall is forecast early tomorrow morning which will cause river levels to rise again, peaking at about 12:00 noon on 04/11/2023.

items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.91 m and is steady.

The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.79 m and is rising gradually by approximately 12 mm per hour.

Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m.

We are unable to pump at Huish Episcopi pumping station due to high river levels.

Further heavy rainfall is forecast tomorrow morning which will cause river levels to respond again likely to peak at 12:00 noon on 04/11/2023.

items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is likely throughout today, Friday 3 November and into tomorrow. High water levels may last for a few days. This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system and recent rainfall. Areas most at risk are, Ridlington, Briggate, Honing, East Rushton, Dilham, Sutton, Catfield Common, Hickling, Potter Heigham, Ludham, Bastwick, Martham, Damgate and Billockby, and the A149 and A1062 roads.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message tomorrow, Saturday 4 November.

The risk of flooding to properties at Leatherhead from Storm Ciaran has now reduced.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  

A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land. The weather remains unsettled over the next few days and rainfall tomorrow, Saturday 04/11/23, may cause river levels to rise again.

Our incident staff are monitoring the situation closely and will issue further messages if required.  Please take photographs of any flood damage and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.56m and is stable.

Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.

The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 6.20 m and is rising by approximately 30 mm per hour.

There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30 m.

Pumping is taking place at Saltmoor and Northmoor pumping stations.

Scattered showers are forecast for today 03/11/2023 and a heavier band of rain Saturday morning.

The River Tone at Currymoor is forecast to remain high as a result.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the intense rainfall over the last few weeks. The more westerly communities on the Chalk in Dorset, including those along the South Winterbourne Valley will start to experience issues with septic tanks and roads may become flooded. Levels are expected to continue rising until at least the end of next week. You can monitor groundwater levels at the Kingston Russell borehole on the Check-for-Flooding.gov.uk website.
Further heavy rainfall is expected tomorrow, Saturday with a further band arriving in the middle of next week.
Please avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can flood nearby properties and can seriously damage your engine. If there is no alternative please drive very slowly to minimise damage. 
If you have property flood resilience measures such as pumps, air brick covers or flood barriers, you should consider putting them in place now. 
This message will be updated on Saturday.
